get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Disputing Unauthorized Charges
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Discovering an unauthorized charge on your account can be stressful and frustrating. Whether it's a small amount or a significant sum, the presence of a charge you did not approve demands immediate attention. This article provides a comprehensive guide on how to dispute unauthorized charges, what rights you have as a consumer, and how to prevent similar issues in the future.

### What Are Unauthorized Charges?
Unauthorized charges are transactions made to your account without your permission. These can occur due to various reasons such as credit card theft, data breaches, scams, or simple clerical errors. Common examples include unfamiliar merchant names, duplicated transactions, or recurring subscriptions you never signed up for.

### Step-by-Step Guide to Disputing Unauthorized Charges

#### 1. Review Your Statement
Start by reviewing your account statement or transaction history to identify the charge in question. Sometimes, company names on statements appear differently than expected. A quick internet search or contacting the business directly can clarify whether the charge is legitimate.

#### 2. Contact the Merchant
If you suspect an error or unrecognized charge, contact the merchant first. They may be able to resolve the issue without escalating it to the bank or card issuer. In some cases, honest mistakes such as duplicate billing can be reversed promptly by the business.

#### 3. Notify Your Bank or Card Issuer
If the merchant cannot resolve the issue or if the charge is clearly fraudulent, immediately contact your bank or credit card provider. Most financial institutions have dedicated dispute resolution processes. Reporting quickly increases the chances of a favorable resolution.

#### 4. Submit a Formal Dispute
You may need to submit a dispute form through your bank’s online portal or app. Provide as much detail as possible, including transaction date, amount, and why you believe it was unauthorized. Attach supporting documents like emails, receipts, or screenshots.

#### 5. Monitor the Case
After filing the dispute, your financial institution will investigate the matter, which can take several days to a few weeks. You may receive a provisional credit while the issue is being reviewed. Stay in touch and provide any requested information promptly.

### Legal Protections for Consumers
U.S. consumers are protected under the Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) and the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA), depending on the account type. For credit cards, the FCBA limits your liability to $50 for unauthorized transactions if reported within 60 days. For debit cards, reporting within two business days can limit your liability to $50; delay beyond that increases your exposure.

### Tips to Avoid Unauthorized Charges
- Use strong, unique passwords and enable two-factor authentication.
- Monitor your accounts regularly using mobile alerts.
- Be cautious with online purchases and avoid sharing card details via unsecured channels.
- Use virtual credit card numbers for online shopping.
- Keep an eye on children’s purchases on shared accounts or app stores.

### Conclusion
Unauthorized charges are more common than many realize, but quick and informed action can help you recover your funds. Always monitor your accounts, take advantage of consumer protection laws, and don’t hesitate to challenge suspicious transactions. A vigilant approach is your best defense.

#### 2. Contact the Merchant

#### 3. Request a Refund

If you’ve exhausted the merchant options, initiate a dispute with your bank. Many credit card providers offer robust dispute resolution services for erroneous charges.

- **SaaS Vendors**: Read the terms carefully. Many offer refunds within a trial window.

### Best Practices to Prevent Accidental Charges
- Turn off one-click purchases in account settings.
- Enable transaction alerts on your phone.
- Set calendar reminders for subscription renewals.
- Use prepaid cards for high-risk or trial signups.
- Create family controls or approval gates on devices used by children.

### Conclusion
Accidental charges are frustrating but usually fixable. The key is to act quickly, document everything, and know your rights. With the right approach, you can often secure a refund and put safeguards in place to prevent future issues.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Adjusting Incorrect Billing Amounts
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Incorrect billing amounts can cause confusion and financial strain if left uncorrected. Whether it’s an overstated utility bill, an unexpected telecom fee, or a miscalculated invoice, addressing these discrepancies promptly is key to maintaining both your finances and peace of mind. Here’s a comprehensive guide on how to correct incorrect billing amounts.

### What Constitutes an Incorrect Billing Amount?
This refers to any bill or invoice where the amount charged does not match the agreed-upon amount, service usage, or contract terms. Examples include:
- Extra line items you didn’t purchase
- Incorrect service charges (e.g., being billed for premium access when only basic service was used)
- Mismatched tax or shipping rates
- Typographical or system errors

### First Steps to Take

#### 1. Review the Bill in Detail
Cross-check every item in the bill or invoice with your original contract or receipt. Take note of any discrepancies.

#### 2. Gather Documentation
Prepare copies of prior bills, contracts, receipts, or emails that support your claim. Having detailed records helps build a strong case.

#### 3. Contact Customer Service
Reach out to the billing department via phone or email. Politely explain the discrepancy, referencing specific line items. Include copies of your documentation.

#### 4. Request a Correction or Adjustment
Ask for a revised bill or an account credit. Most reputable companies will investigate and correct the issue within a billing cycle or two.

#### 5. Follow Up
If the issue isn’t resolved on first contact, escalate to a manager or file a formal dispute. Be persistent, professional, and clear in your communication.

### Tools to Help You
- **Bill negotiation services** like Truebill or BillFixers
- **Spreadsheets or budgeting apps** to monitor charges
- **Email templates** for professional dispute letters
- **Account portals** where you can download or compare prior bills

### Legal Options
If your issue isn’t resolved and the amount is significant, consider:
- Filing a complaint with the FTC or your state’s attorney general
- Reporting to industry regulators (e.g., FCC for telecom bills)
- Taking the company to small claims court

### Tips to Avoid Future Billing Errors
- Read contracts carefully before signing
- Set up automatic alerts for new bills
- Always verify your payment confirmation against the original bill
- Request detailed invoices and keep backups of all receipts

### Conclusion
Incorrect billing amounts are common but usually correctable. Stay calm, be methodical, and assert your right to fair and accurate billing. The sooner you act, the easier it is to rectify the mistake and protect your finances.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Discovering an unauthorized charge on your account can be stressful and frustrating. Whether it's a small amount or a significant sum, the presence of a charge you did not approve demands immediate attention. This article provides a comprehensive guide on how to dispute unauthorized charges, what rights you have as a consumer, and how to prevent similar issues in the future.

### What Are Unauthorized Charges?
Unauthorized charges are transactions made to your account without your permission. These can occur due to various reasons such as credit card theft, data breaches, scams, or simple clerical errors. Common examples include unfamiliar merchant names, duplicated transactions, or recurring subscriptions you never signed up for.

### Step-by-Step Guide to Disputing Unauthorized Charges

#### 1. Review Your Statement
Start by reviewing your account statement or transaction history to identify the charge in question. Sometimes, company names on statements appear differently than expected. A quick internet search or contacting the business directly can clarify whether the charge is legitimate.

#### 2. Contact the Merchant
If you suspect an error or unrecognized charge, contact the merchant first. They may be able to resolve the issue without escalating it to the bank or card issuer. In some cases, honest mistakes such as duplicate billing can be reversed promptly by the business.

#### 3. Notify Your Bank or Card Issuer
If the merchant cannot resolve the issue or if the charge is clearly fraudulent, immediately contact your bank or credit card provider. Most financial institutions have dedicated dispute resolution processes. Reporting quickly increases the chances of a favorable resolution.

#### 4. Submit a Formal Dispute
You may need to submit a dispute form through your bank’s online portal or app. Provide as much detail as possible, including transaction date, amount, and why you believe it was unauthorized. Attach supporting documents like emails, receipts, or screenshots.

#### 5. Monitor the Case
After filing the dispute, your financial institution will investigate the matter, which can take several days to a few weeks. You may receive a provisional credit while the issue is being reviewed. Stay in touch and provide any requested information promptly.

### Legal Protections for Consumers
U.S. consumers are protected under the Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) and the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA), depending on the account type. For credit cards, the FCBA limits your liability to $50 for unauthorized transactions if reported within 60 days. For debit cards, reporting within two business days can limit your liability to $50; delay beyond that increases your exposure.

### Tips to Avoid Unauthorized Charges
- Use strong, unique passwords and enable two-factor authentication.
- Monitor your accounts regularly using mobile alerts.
- Be cautious with online purchases and avoid sharing card details via unsecured channels.
- Use virtual credit card numbers for online shopping.
- Keep an eye on children’s purchases on shared accounts or app stores.

### Conclusion
Unauthorized charges are more common than many realize, but quick and informed action can help you recover your funds. Always monitor your accounts, take advantage of consumer protection laws, and don’t hesitate to challenge suspicious transactions. A vigilant approach is your best defense.

- Use prepaid cards for high-risk or trial signups.
- Create family controls or approval gates on devices used by children.

### Conclusion

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Adjusting Incorrect Billing Amounts
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Incorrect billing amounts can cause confusion and financial strain if left uncorrected. Whether it’s an overstated utility bill, an unexpected telecom fee, or a miscalculated invoice, addressing these discrepancies promptly is key to maintaining both your finances and peace of mind. Here’s a comprehensive guide on how to correct incorrect billing amounts.

### What Constitutes an Incorrect Billing Amount?
This refers to any bill or invoice where the amount charged does not match the agreed-upon amount, service usage, or contract terms. Examples include:
- Extra line items you didn’t purchase
- Incorrect service charges (e.g., being billed for premium access when only basic service was used)
- Mismatched tax or shipping rates
- Typographical or system errors

### First Steps to Take

#### 1. Review the Bill in Detail
Cross-check every item in the bill or invoice with your original contract or receipt. Take note of any discrepancies.

#### 2. Gather Documentation
Prepare copies of prior bills, contracts, receipts, or emails that support your claim. Having detailed records helps build a strong case.

#### 3. Contact Customer Service
Reach out to the billing department via phone or email. Politely explain the discrepancy, referencing specific line items. Include copies of your documentation.

#### 4. Request a Correction or Adjustment
Ask for a revised bill or an account credit. Most reputable companies will investigate and correct the issue within a billing cycle or two.

#### 5. Follow Up
If the issue isn’t resolved on first contact, escalate to a manager or file a formal dispute. Be persistent, professional, and clear in your communication.

### Tools to Help You
- **Bill negotiation services** like Truebill or BillFixers
- **Spreadsheets or budgeting apps** to monitor charges
- **Email templates** for professional dispute letters
- **Account portals** where you can download or compare prior bills

### Legal Options
If your issue isn’t resolved and the amount is significant, consider:
- Filing a complaint with the FTC or your state’s attorney general
- Reporting to industry regulators (e.g., FCC for telecom bills)
- Taking the company to small claims court

### Tips to Avoid Future Billing Errors
- Read contracts carefully before signing
- Set up automatic alerts for new bills
- Always verify your payment confirmation against the original bill
- Request detailed invoices and keep backups of all receipts

### Conclusion
Incorrect billing amounts are common but usually correctable. Stay calm, be methodical, and assert your right to fair and accurate billing. The sooner you act, the easier it is to rectify the mistake and protect your finances.

Double-check the total against the itemized list or your original agreement. If you notice an inflated charge, highlight it.

#### 2. Contact the Vendor
Reach out to the store, website, or provider. Be polite but firm. Many issues are resolved immediately, especially if the error is obvious.

#### 3. Provide Proof
Show receipts, screenshots, advertisements, or past statements to demonstrate the correct amount. Clarity helps resolve disputes quickly.

#### 4. Ask for a Refund or Adjustment
Clearly state your expectation: refund, credit, or corrected invoice. Request a written confirmation or updated receipt.

#### 5. Escalate When Necessary
If the frontline representative isn’t helpful, ask for a supervisor or file a complaint. Use online reviews or forums to apply public pressure if needed.

### Know Your Rights
In many regions, consumer protection laws require businesses to honor advertised prices. Overcharging can be considered deceptive or unfair under these laws.

- **U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC)** handles pricing violations
- **State Attorneys General** can investigate repeated offenses
- **Industry regulators** (e.g., for insurance or telecom) provide escalation channels

### Preventing Overcharges
- Always check receipts before leaving a store
- Enable real-time transaction alerts on your bank app
- Opt for email invoices for traceability
- Keep screenshots of online checkout pages
- Compare recurring bills against your service agreement

### Conclusion
Handling overcharges doesn’t have to be a stressful ordeal. With a structured approach, timely action, and proper documentation, you can recover excess payments and help companies improve their billing practices. Being proactive protects your wallet and helps maintain fairness in the marketplace.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Complete Guide to Data Export Options
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Data portability and accessibility are fundamental to modern business operations. Our platform provides comprehensive data export capabilities designed to integrate seamlessly with your existing workflows and reporting systems. This guide covers all available export options, best practices, and advanced techniques for extracting your data efficiently.

### Overview of Export Methods

Our platform supports multiple export methods to accommodate different use cases and technical requirements. Whether you need real-time data access through APIs, scheduled batch exports, or manual downloads for ad-hoc analysis, we provide flexible solutions that scale with your needs.

#### Manual Export via Dashboard
The simplest method for exporting data is through our web dashboard. Navigate to any report or data view, and click the export button in the top-right corner. You can choose from multiple formats including CSV, Excel (XLSX), JSON, and PDF. Manual exports are ideal for:
- Ad-hoc reporting needs
- Quick data snapshots
- Sharing specific datasets with stakeholders
- Creating backup copies of important data

The manual export feature includes options to customize date ranges, filter specific fields, and apply existing saved filters. Export jobs are processed in the background, and you'll receive an email notification with a secure download link once your export is ready.

#### API-Based Export
For programmatic access and integration with other systems, our RESTful API provides comprehensive data export capabilities. The API supports:
- Pagination for large datasets
- Custom field selection
- Advanced filtering and sorting
- Multiple response formats (JSON, CSV, XML)
- Webhook notifications for completed exports
- Rate limiting to ensure platform stability

API exports are perfect for building automated reporting pipelines, integrating with business intelligence tools, or creating custom applications that leverage your data. Authentication is handled via API keys, which can be managed in your account settings.

#### Scheduled Exports
Enterprise plan users have access to our scheduled export feature, which automatically generates and delivers reports according to your specified schedule. Configure exports to run:
- Daily, weekly, or monthly
- At specific times to align with business processes
- With dynamic date ranges (e.g., "last 7 days")
- To multiple recipients via email
- To external systems via FTP, SFTP, or cloud storage

Scheduled exports eliminate manual work and ensure stakeholders always have access to the latest data. You can create multiple export schedules for different datasets and audiences.

### Supported File Formats

#### CSV (Comma-Separated Values)
CSV is the most universally supported format, compatible with virtually all spreadsheet and database applications. Our CSV exports include:
- UTF-8 encoding for international character support
- Configurable delimiters (comma, tab, pipe)
- Optional header row
- Proper escaping of special characters
- Support for large files (up to 5GB)

#### Excel (XLSX)
For users who prefer working in Microsoft Excel, we provide native XLSX exports with:
- Multiple worksheets for related datasets
- Formatted cells with proper data types
- Frozen header rows
- Basic styling and conditional formatting
- Pivot table-ready data structures

#### JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
JSON exports are ideal for developers and technical users who need structured data for further processing:
- Nested object support
- Array handling for multi-value fields
- Consistent formatting and indentation
- Schema documentation available
- Compressed options for large datasets

#### PDF Reports
For presentation and archival purposes, PDF exports provide:
- Professional formatting and branding
- Charts and visualizations
- Page headers and footers
- Table of contents for long reports
- Password protection options

### Best Practices for Data Export

1. **Plan Your Export Strategy**: Before exporting, consider your end goal. Are you creating a one-time report or establishing an ongoing process? This will help you choose the right export method.

2. **Use Filters Wisely**: Export only the data you need. Applying appropriate filters reduces file sizes and processing time while making the data more manageable.

3. **Consider Data Privacy**: When exporting sensitive data, use our built-in anonymization features and ensure you're complying with relevant data protection regulations.

4. **Optimize for Performance**: For large datasets, consider using API pagination or breaking exports into smaller chunks. This prevents timeouts and ensures reliable delivery.

5. **Maintain Data Integrity**: Use our export validation features to ensure data completeness and accuracy. Set up checksums for critical exports.

### Advanced Features

#### Custom Templates
Create reusable export templates that define specific fields, filters, and formatting options. Templates can be shared across your organization for consistency.

#### Data Transformation
Apply transformations during export to format data according to your needs:
- Date format conversion
- Currency conversion
- Field concatenation or splitting
- Custom calculations
- Data masking for sensitive fields

#### Export Audit Trail
All exports are logged in our audit system, providing:
- Complete history of who exported what and when
- File download tracking
- Compliance reporting
- Usage analytics

### Integration Examples

Many of our customers integrate our export capabilities with popular business tools:
- **Tableau**: Use our API to create live data connections
- **Power BI**: Schedule exports to OneDrive for automatic refresh
- **Google Sheets**: Import data using our CSV export URLs
- **Salesforce**: Sync data using our webhook notifications
- **Custom Dashboards**: Build real-time displays using our streaming API

### Troubleshooting Common Issues

- **Export Timeouts**: For exports taking longer than 5 minutes, consider reducing the date range or number of fields
- **Character Encoding**: Ensure your import tool supports UTF-8 if you're working with international data
- **File Size Limits**: Exports larger than 5GB need to be split into multiple files
- **Access Permissions**: Verify your account has the necessary permissions for the data you're trying to export

### Security Considerations

We take data security seriously. All exports are:
- Encrypted in transit using TLS 1.3
- Available via time-limited secure download links
- Logged for audit purposes
- Subject to your account's security policies
- Optionally encrypted at rest for scheduled exports

For additional security, consider using our encrypted export option, which password-protects files using AES-256 encryption.

### Getting Help

If you need assistance with data exports:
- Check our API documentation for technical details
- Contact your dedicated account manager (Enterprise plans)
- Use our in-app chat for immediate support
- Visit our community forum for tips from other users
- Schedule a training session for your team

Remember, efficient data export is key to maximizing the value of your data. Take time to explore all available options and choose the methods that best fit your workflow.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: API Export Documentation and Best Practices
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
The API is the backbone of programmatic data export, offering flexibility and power for developers and technical users. This comprehensive documentation covers everything you need to know about leveraging our API for data export, including authentication, endpoints, parameters, best practices, and real-world examples that will help you build robust data export solutions.

### Getting Started with API Authentication

Before making any API calls, you need to authenticate your requests. We support multiple authentication methods to suit different security requirements and use cases:

#### API Key Authentication
The simplest method for getting started:
```
GET /api/v2/export/data
Headers:
  X-API-Key: your-api-key-here
  Content-Type: application/json
```

API keys can be generated in your account settings and should be treated as passwords. Each key can be scoped to specific permissions, allowing you to create keys with read-only access for export operations. We recommend rotating keys every 90 days and immediately revoking any compromised keys.

#### OAuth 2.0 Authentication
For applications that need to access data on behalf of users:
- **Authorization Code Flow**: Best for web applications
- **Client Credentials Flow**: Ideal for server-to-server communication
- **Refresh Tokens**: Automatically renew access without user intervention
- **Scope Management**: Fine-grained control over data access

OAuth provides better security for multi-user applications and allows users to revoke access without sharing credentials.

#### JWT Bearer Tokens
For advanced integrations requiring stateless authentication:
- **Self-Contained**: All authorization data included in the token
- **Short-Lived**: Typically expire after 1 hour for security
- **Claims-Based**: Include custom claims for row-level security
- **RS256 Signing**: Industry-standard cryptographic signing

### Core Export Endpoints

#### Standard Export Endpoint
```
POST /api/v2/export/data
```
This is the primary endpoint for most export operations. It supports:
- **Flexible Filtering**: Complex query conditions using our filter DSL
- **Field Selection**: Choose exactly which fields to include
- **Sorting**: Multi-field sorting with direction control
- **Pagination**: Handle large datasets efficiently
- **Format Selection**: Specify output format in the Accept header

#### Asynchronous Export Endpoint
```
POST /api/v2/export/async
```
For large exports that may take several minutes:
1. Submit export request and receive job ID
2. Poll job status endpoint for completion
3. Download results from provided URL
4. Automatic cleanup after 7 days

This approach prevents timeout issues and allows for better resource management on both client and server sides.

#### Streaming Export Endpoint
```
GET /api/v2/export/stream
```
Real-time data streaming using Server-Sent Events:
- **Continuous Updates**: Receive new records as they're created
- **Backpressure Support**: Client controls data flow rate
- **Automatic Reconnection**: Resume from last received record
- **Filtering Support**: Apply same filters as standard export

### Request Parameters and Options

#### Filter Language
Our powerful filter language supports complex queries:
```json
{
  "filter": {
    "$and": [
      {"status": "active"},
      {"created_date": {"$gte": "2024-01-01"}},
      {
        "$or": [
          {"category": "premium"},
          {"value": {"$gt": 1000}}
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

Supported operators include:
- **Comparison**: `$eq`, `$ne`, `$gt`, `$gte`, `$lt`, `$lte`
- **Logical**: `$and`, `$or`, `$not`
- **Array**: `$in`, `$nin`, `$all`
- **Text**: `$contains`, `$startsWith`, `$endsWith`
- **Existence**: `$exists`, `$type`
- **Regex**: `$regex` with flags support

#### Field Selection
Optimize payload size by requesting only needed fields:
```json
{
  "fields": ["id", "name", "email", "created_date"],
  "exclude_fields": ["internal_notes", "password_hash"]
}
```

You can also use dot notation for nested fields:
```json
{
  "fields": ["id", "profile.name", "profile.email", "settings.notifications"]
}
```

#### Pagination Strategies
We offer multiple pagination methods:

**Offset-Based Pagination**:
```json
{
  "offset": 1000,
  "limit": 100
}
```
Simple but can miss records if data changes during pagination.

**Cursor-Based Pagination**:
```json
{
  "cursor": "eyJpZCI6MTIzNDU2fQ==",
  "limit": 100
}
```
More reliable for large datasets, guarantees you won't miss records.

**Keyset Pagination**:
```json
{
  "after_id": "12345",
  "limit": 100
}
```
Most efficient for ordered datasets, ideal for incremental exports.

### Response Formats and Handling

#### JSON Response Structure
```json
{
  "data": [...],
  "metadata": {
    "total_count": 10000,
    "returned_count": 100,
    "has_more": true,
    "cursor": "eyJpZCI6MTM0NTY3fQ=="
  },
  "links": {
    "self": "/api/v2/export/data?cursor=current",
    "next": "/api/v2/export/data?cursor=next",
    "download": "/api/v2/export/download/job-id"
  }
}
```

#### CSV Response Handling
When requesting CSV format:
- Set `Accept: text/csv` header
- Response streams directly without JSON wrapper
- Column headers included by default
- Configure delimiter with `csv_delimiter` parameter
- Handle special characters with `csv_quote_style`

#### Error Response Format
Consistent error structure for easy handling:
```json
{
  "error": {
    "code": "RATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED",
    "message": "Too many requests. Please retry after 60 seconds.",
    "details": {
      "limit": 1000,
      "window": "1h",
      "retry_after": 60
    }
  }
}
```

### Rate Limiting and Performance

#### Rate Limit Tiers
- **Standard**: 1,000 requests per hour
- **Professional**: 5,000 requests per hour
- **Enterprise**: Custom limits based on needs
- **Burst Allowance**: 10x limit for 1 minute per day

Rate limit information included in response headers:
```
X-RateLimit-Limit: 5000
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 4995
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1628790000
```

#### Performance Optimization Tips

1. **Use Field Selection**: Only request fields you need
2. **Implement Caching**: Cache repeated queries client-side
3. **Batch Operations**: Combine multiple small requests
4. **Compression**: Enable gzip with `Accept-Encoding: gzip`
5. **Parallel Requests**: Use multiple connections for large exports
6. **Connection Pooling**: Reuse HTTP connections
7. **Retry Logic**: Implement exponential backoff

### Advanced Export Patterns

#### Incremental Export Pattern
```python
import requests
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

def incremental_export(api_key, last_sync_time):
    headers = {'X-API-Key': api_key}
    params = {
        'filter': {
            'modified_date': {'$gte': last_sync_time}
        },
        'sort': [{'modified_date': 'asc'}],
        'limit': 1000
    }
    
    all_records = []
    has_more = True
    
    while has_more:
        response = requests.post(
            'https://api.company.com/v2/export/data',
            headers=headers,
            json=params
        )
        
        data = response.json()
        all_records.extend(data['data'])
        
        has_more = data['metadata']['has_more']
        if has_more:
            params['cursor'] = data['metadata']['cursor']
    
    return all_records
```

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Security is paramount in today's digital landscape, and our platform provides enterprise-grade security features designed to protect your data, ensure compliance, and give you complete control over user access. This comprehensive guide covers all security features available across our platform, with detailed explanations of how to implement and manage each feature to create a robust security posture for your organization.

### Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

Multi-factor authentication adds an essential layer of security beyond traditional passwords. Our platform supports various MFA methods to accommodate different security requirements and user preferences:

#### Available MFA Methods
- **Time-based One-Time Passwords (TOTP)**: Compatible with apps like Google Authenticator, Microsoft Authenticator, and Authy
- **SMS Verification**: Text message codes sent to registered mobile devices
- **Email Verification**: Backup method using secure email codes
- **Hardware Security Keys**: Support for FIDO2/WebAuthn devices like YubiKey
- **Biometric Authentication**: Fingerprint and facial recognition on supported devices
- **Push Notifications**: One-tap approval through our mobile app

#### MFA Implementation Best Practices
1. **Mandatory Enforcement**: Require MFA for all users with access to sensitive data
2. **Gradual Rollout**: Phase implementation to minimize user disruption
3. **Backup Methods**: Always configure at least two MFA methods per user
4. **Recovery Codes**: Generate and securely store one-time recovery codes
5. **Regular Reviews**: Audit MFA usage and update policies as needed

### Single Sign-On (SSO) Integration

Our SSO capabilities streamline user access while maintaining security through centralized authentication:

#### Supported SSO Protocols
- **SAML 2.0**: Industry-standard protocol for enterprise SSO
- **OAuth 2.0**: Modern authorization framework
- **OpenID Connect**: Identity layer built on OAuth 2.0
- **LDAP/Active Directory**: Direct integration with corporate directories
- **Custom Protocols**: API support for proprietary authentication systems

#### Popular SSO Provider Integrations
- **Microsoft Azure AD**: Seamless integration with Office 365
- **Okta**: Pre-built connector with automated provisioning
- **Google Workspace**: One-click setup for Google accounts
- **OneLogin**: Full lifecycle management support
- **Ping Identity**: Advanced federation capabilities
- **Custom SAML**: Configure any SAML-compliant provider

#### SSO Configuration Steps
1. Choose your identity provider
2. Configure SAML endpoints and certificates
3. Map user attributes between systems
4. Test with pilot group
5. Enable for all users
6. Monitor authentication logs

### Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

Our RBAC system provides granular control over user permissions:

#### Predefined Roles
- **Super Admin**: Full system access and configuration
- **Admin**: User management and most settings
- **Manager**: Department-level access and reporting
- **User**: Standard access to assigned resources
- **Viewer**: Read-only access
- **Guest**: Time-limited access to specific resources

#### Custom Role Creation
Create roles tailored to your organization:
1. Define role name and description
2. Select specific permissions from 200+ options
3. Set data access boundaries
4. Configure approval workflows
5. Assign users or groups

#### Permission Categories
- **Data Access**: Read, write, delete, export permissions
- **User Management**: Create, modify, deactivate users
- **System Configuration**: Settings, integrations, security policies
- **Reporting**: View, create, schedule reports
- **API Access**: Endpoint-specific permissions
- **Audit Functions**: View logs, generate compliance reports

### IP Whitelisting and Geographic Restrictions

Control access based on network location and geography:

#### IP Whitelisting Features
- **Static IP Ranges**: Define allowed corporate networks
- **Dynamic Updates**: API for updating allowed IPs
- **User-Specific Rules**: Different restrictions per user/role
- **Bypass Options**: Temporary access for travel
- **IPv6 Support**: Full support for modern networks

#### Geographic Restrictions
- **Country-Level Blocking**: Prevent access from specific countries
- **Geofencing**: Define allowed access regions
- **VPN Detection**: Optional blocking of VPN connections
- **Travel Policies**: Temporary geographic exemptions
- **Compliance Mode**: Automatic restrictions based on data residency laws

### Session Management

Comprehensive control over user sessions:

#### Session Security Features
- **Configurable Timeouts**: Set idle and absolute session limits
- **Concurrent Session Limits**: Restrict simultaneous logins
- **Device Fingerprinting**: Track and authorize specific devices
- **Session Recording**: Optional activity recording for compliance
- **Force Logout**: Administrative session termination
- **Remember Me Options**: Secure persistent sessions

#### Session Monitoring
- **Active Session Dashboard**: Real-time view of all sessions
- **Anomaly Detection**: Alert on suspicious session behavior
- **Location Tracking**: Monitor session geographic origins
- **Device Analytics**: Track device types and browsers
- **Session History**: Complete audit trail of all sessions

### Data Encryption

Multi-layer encryption protects data at all stages:

#### Encryption at Rest
- **AES-256 Encryption**: Industry-standard encryption for stored data
- **Key Management**: Automated key rotation every 90 days
- **Database Encryption**: Transparent data encryption (TDE)
- **File Storage**: Encrypted object storage for attachments
- **Backup Encryption**: Secure backup data protection

#### Encryption in Transit
- **TLS 1.3**: Latest protocol for all connections
- **Certificate Pinning**: Mobile app certificate validation
- **Perfect Forward Secrecy**: Unique keys per session
- **HSTS**: Enforce secure connections
- **API Encryption**: All API calls use HTTPS

#### Field-Level Encryption
- **Sensitive Data Protection**: Encrypt specific fields
- **Format Preserving Encryption**: Maintain data usability
- **Tokenization**: Replace sensitive data with tokens
- **Key Per Field**: Separate keys for different data types
- **Search Capabilities**: Encrypted search functionality

### Audit Logging and Compliance

Comprehensive logging for security and compliance:

#### Logged Events
- **Authentication**: All login attempts and methods
- **Authorization**: Permission checks and denials
- **Data Access**: Read, write, delete operations
- **Configuration Changes**: System setting modifications
- **User Management**: Account lifecycle events
- **API Usage**: All API calls with parameters

#### Log Management Features
- **Immutable Storage**: Tamper-proof log storage
- **Long-Term Retention**: Configure retention up to 7 years
- **Real-Time Streaming**: Export logs to SIEM systems
- **Advanced Search**: Query logs with complex filters
- **Automated Reports**: Scheduled compliance reports
- **Alert Rules**: Real-time notifications for security events

#### Compliance Support
- **SOC 2 Type II**: Annual audits and reports
- **ISO 27001**: Information security certification
- **GDPR**: Privacy controls and data management
- **HIPAA**: Healthcare data protection features
- **PCI DSS**: Payment card data security
- **CCPA**: California privacy law compliance

### Security Monitoring and Alerts

Proactive security monitoring protects against threats:

#### Threat Detection
- **Brute Force Protection**: Lock accounts after failed attempts
- **Anomaly Detection**: ML-based unusual behavior identification
- **Impossible Travel**: Alert on geographic impossibilities
- **Data Exfiltration**: Monitor large data exports
- **Privilege Escalation**: Detect unauthorized permission changes

#### Alert Configuration
- **Multi-Channel Alerts**: Email, SMS, push notifications
- **Severity Levels**: Critical, high, medium, low
- **Custom Rules**: Define organization-specific alerts
- **Alert Fatigue Prevention**: Smart grouping and suppression
- **Integration Options**: Send to ticketing systems
- **Escalation Policies**: Automatic escalation for critical events

### API Security

Protect programmatic access to your data:

#### API Authentication
- **API Keys**: Scoped keys with specific permissions
- **OAuth 2.0**: Secure third-party integrations
- **JWT Tokens**: Stateless authentication
- **mTLS**: Mutual TLS for highest security
- **HMAC Signing**: Request integrity verification

#### API Security Features
- **Rate Limiting**: Prevent abuse and ensure availability
- **IP Restrictions**: Limit API access by IP
- **Request Signing**: Cryptographic request verification
- **Response Encryption**: Optional payload encryption
- **CORS Policies**: Control cross-origin access
- **API Versioning**: Maintain security across versions

### Security Best Practices

1. **Defense in Depth**: Layer multiple security controls
2. **Least Privilege**: Grant minimum necessary permissions
3. **Regular Audits**: Monthly security reviews
4. **Update Policies**: Keep security policies current
5. **User Training**: Regular security awareness training
6. **Incident Response**: Documented response procedures
7. **Backup Strategy**: Regular backups with encryption
8. **Vendor Management**: Assess third-party security
9. **Penetration Testing**: Annual security assessments
10. **Continuous Monitoring**: Real-time security visibility

### Getting Started with Security

1. **Assessment**: Review current security posture
2. **Planning**: Develop implementation roadmap
3. **Implementation**: Deploy features systematically
4. **Testing**: Verify security controls work correctly
5. **Training**: Educate users and administrators
6. **Monitoring**: Establish ongoing security monitoring
7. **Improvement**: Regular reviews and updates

For assistance with security configuration, contact our security team or schedule a security consultation through your account manager.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: User Access Control and Management Guide
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Effective user access control is fundamental to maintaining security and operational efficiency in any organization. This comprehensive guide covers all aspects of user management, from initial provisioning to ongoing access reviews, helping you establish and maintain a robust access control framework that scales with your organization while ensuring security and compliance.

### User Lifecycle Management

Managing users throughout their relationship with your organization requires careful planning and consistent execution. Our platform provides comprehensive tools to handle every stage of the user lifecycle:

#### User Provisioning

The user provisioning process sets the foundation for secure access:

**Manual Provisioning**
1. Navigate to User Management dashboard
2. Click "Add New User"
3. Enter user details (name, email, department)
4. Assign initial role and permissions
5. Set temporary password or send invitation
6. Configure MFA requirements
7. Add to appropriate groups
8. Set access expiration if needed

**Bulk Provisioning**
- **CSV Import**: Upload user lists with predefined attributes
- **API Integration**: Programmatic user creation
- **SCIM Support**: Automated provisioning from HR systems
- **Template-Based**: Create users from role templates
- **Approval Workflows**: Require manager approval for access

**Automated Provisioning**
Integrate with your HR systems for automatic user creation:
- Workday connector for employee synchronization
- Active Directory sync for corporate users
- Google Workspace integration
- Custom webhooks for proprietary systems
- Rule-based role assignment

#### User Modification

As users' roles change, their access must be updated accordingly:

**Role Transitions**
- **Promotion Workflows**: Automatic permission upgrades
- **Department Transfers**: Reassign group memberships
- **Project-Based Access**: Temporary permission grants
- **Leave of Absence**: Suspend without deletion
- **Contractor Conversions**: Change user types

**Access Request Management**
1. User submits access request through portal
2. Request routes to appropriate approver
3. Approver reviews justification
4. Approval triggers automatic provisioning
5. Notification sent to user
6. Access logged for audit

#### User Deprovisioning

Secure offboarding protects against unauthorized access:

**Immediate Actions**
- Disable account access
- Revoke all active sessions
- Cancel pending access requests
- Remove from all groups
- Disable API keys
- Block VPN access

**Retention Actions**
- Transfer data ownership
- Archive user activity logs
- Maintain audit trail
- Preserve compliance records
- Export user data if required
- Schedule permanent deletion

### Group Management

Groups simplify permission management for large user populations:

#### Group Types

**Organizational Groups**
- **Department-Based**: Sales, Marketing, Engineering
- **Location-Based**: Regional access controls
- **Role-Based**: Managers, Analysts, Administrators
- **Project-Based**: Temporary collaborative groups
- **Compliance-Based**: PCI, HIPAA access groups

**Dynamic Groups**
Automatically maintain membership based on attributes:
- Job title contains "Manager"
- Department equals "Finance"
- Location includes "Europe"
- Account age greater than 90 days
- Certification status is valid

#### Group Hierarchies

Create nested group structures:
```
Organization
├── North America
│   ├── USA
│   │   ├── East Coast
│   │   └── West Coast
│   └── Canada
└── Europe
    ├── UK
    └── EU
```

Permissions inherit down the hierarchy, simplifying management.

#### Group Policies

**Access Policies**
- Maximum group size limits
- Automatic expiration dates
- Required approval levels
- Mutual exclusion rules
- Time-based access windows

**Membership Policies**
- Self-service join options
- Manager approval requirements
- Automatic removal triggers
- Regular attestation cycles
- Guest member restrictions

### Permission Management

Granular permissions ensure users have appropriate access:

#### Permission Types

**System Permissions**
- Login access
- Password change
- Profile management
- MFA configuration
- API usage
- Support ticket creation

**Data Permissions**
- Read access
- Write access
- Delete rights
- Export capabilities
- Share permissions
- Bulk operations

**Feature Permissions**
- Report creation
- Dashboard customization
- Integration management
- Workflow design
- Alert configuration
- Archive access

#### Permission Inheritance

Understand how permissions cascade:
1. **User-Level**: Direct assignments (highest priority)
2. **Primary Group**: Main group permissions
3. **Secondary Groups**: Additional group permissions
4. **Organization Default**: Baseline permissions
5. **Role Template**: Standard role permissions

**Conflict Resolution**
- Explicit deny always wins
- Most permissive grant applies
- User-level overrides group-level
- Time-based restrictions enforce
- Compliance rules supersede

#### Permission Delegation

Allow controlled permission management:

**Delegation Scopes**
- Department managers can manage their team
- Project leads assign project permissions
- Regional admins control location access
- Application owners manage app-specific rights
- Compliance officers enforce policy permissions

**Delegation Constraints**
- Cannot grant permissions you don't have
- Cannot exceed delegation scope
- All changes are audited
- Approval workflows enforced
- Regular delegation reviews

### Access Reviews and Certification

Regular access reviews ensure appropriate permissions:

#### Scheduled Reviews

**Review Frequencies**
- **Quarterly**: High-privilege accounts
- **Semi-Annual**: Standard user access
- **Annual**: Low-risk access
- **Continuous**: Critical system access
- **Event-Driven**: Role changes trigger review

**Review Process**
1. System generates access reports
2. Managers receive review assignments
3. Each permission evaluated
4. Decisions recorded (approve/revoke/modify)
5. Changes automatically implemented
6. Exceptions documented
7. Compliance report generated

#### Certification Campaigns

Organize large-scale access reviews:

**Campaign Planning**
- Define scope and timeline
- Identify reviewers
- Set review criteria
- Create review guides
- Schedule reminders
- Plan remediation

**Campaign Execution**
- Launch notifications
- Track progress
- Send reminders
- Escalate delays
- Process decisions
- Generate reports

#### Self-Service Access Reviews

Empower users to review their own access:
- View current permissions
- Identify unused access
- Request removal
- Suggest corrections
- Report concerns
- Track history

### Privileged Access Management (PAM)

Special controls for high-risk access:

#### Privileged Account Types
- **System Administrators**: Full platform access
- **Database Administrators**: Data layer access
- **Security Administrators**: Security configuration
- **Application Administrators**: App-specific privileges
- **Emergency Access**: Break-glass accounts

#### PAM Controls

**Just-In-Time Access**
- Request privileged access when needed
- Automatic approval for pre-approved scenarios
- Time-limited elevation
- Automatic revocation
- Full audit trail

**Privileged Session Management**
- Session recording for compliance
- Real-time monitoring
- Command filtering
- Automatic termination triggers
- Forensic analysis capabilities

**Password Vaulting**
- Secure storage of privileged credentials
- Automatic password rotation
- Check-out/check-in process
- Emergency access procedures
- Integration with password managers

### Segregation of Duties (SoD)

Prevent conflicts of interest and fraud:

#### SoD Rules

**Toxic Combinations**
Define incompatible permission sets:
- Create and approve same transaction
- Access to production and development
- User creation and audit review
- Payment initiation and approval
- Data entry and validation

**Rule Enforcement**
- Preventive controls block violations
- Detective controls identify exceptions
- Compensating controls for necessary violations
- Regular SoD analysis reports
- Automated remediation workflows

#### SoD Monitoring

**Real-Time Monitoring**
- Alert on violation attempts
- Block prohibited combinations
- Log all SoD events
- Escalate to security team
- Track resolution

**Periodic Analysis**
- Monthly SoD reports
- Identify new toxic combinations
- Review existing violations
- Plan remediation
- Update rule library

### Compliance and Auditing

Maintain compliance with access control requirements:

#### Compliance Frameworks

**SOX Compliance**
- Quarterly access certifications
- Segregation of duties enforcement
- Change management controls
- Audit trail maintenance
- Management attestation

**GDPR Requirements**
- Purpose limitation controls
- Data minimization enforcement
- Access request handling
- Right to erasure support
- Cross-border transfer controls

**Industry-Specific**
- HIPAA minimum necessary
- PCI DSS role-based access
- FINRA supervision requirements
- FDA Part 11 controls
- ISO 27001 access management

#### Audit Support

**Audit Preparation**
- Generate access reports
- Document control procedures
- Prepare evidence packages
- Review exception logs
- Update documentation

**Audit Artifacts**
- User access listings
- Permission matrices
- Change logs
- Certification records
- Policy documents
- Training records

### Best Practices for Access Control

1. **Principle of Least Privilege**: Grant minimum necessary access
2. **Regular Reviews**: Implement consistent review cycles
3. **Clear Documentation**: Maintain current access policies
4. **Automated Workflows**: Reduce manual processes
5. **Training Programs**: Educate users and managers
6. **Metrics and Monitoring**: Track access control KPIs
7. **Incident Response**: Plan for access breaches
8. **Continuous Improvement**: Regular process optimization

### Common Challenges and Solutions

**Challenge**: Access creep over time
**Solution**: Implement regular recertification campaigns

**Challenge**: Emergency access requests
**Solution**: Define break-glass procedures with monitoring

**Challenge**: Complex approval chains
**Solution**: Streamline with role-based auto-approval

**Challenge**: Orphaned accounts
**Solution**: Automated discovery and cleanup processes

**Challenge**: Shadow IT access
**Solution**: Regular access discovery audits

### Metrics and KPIs

Track access control effectiveness:
- Average provisioning time
- Percentage of certified access
- Number of orphaned accounts
- SoD violations detected
- Failed access attempts
- Time to deprovision
- Review completion rates
- Policy compliance percentage

For detailed assistance with implementing these access control features, contact your account manager or our security team.

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Preparing for a security audit requires comprehensive documentation, evidence gathering, and a clear understanding of your security controls. This guide provides a complete framework for audit preparation, helping you demonstrate compliance, identify gaps, and continuously improve your security posture. Whether facing internal audits, external assessments, or regulatory examinations, this guide ensures you're fully prepared.

### Understanding Security Audit Types

Different audit types require different preparation strategies:

#### Internal Audits
Conducted by your organization's internal audit team:
- **Scope**: Usually focused on specific controls or processes
- **Frequency**: Quarterly or semi-annual
- **Objective**: Identify improvements and ensure compliance
- **Preparation Time**: 2-4 weeks typically sufficient
- **Documentation Level**: Moderate detail required
- **Follow-up**: Direct remediation plans

#### External Audits
Performed by independent third parties:
- **Scope**: Comprehensive review of all controls
- **Frequency**: Annual or as required
- **Objective**: Provide independent attestation
- **Preparation Time**: 6-8 weeks recommended
- **Documentation Level**: Extensive evidence required
- **Follow-up**: Formal management responses

#### Regulatory Examinations
Conducted by regulatory bodies:
- **Scope**: Compliance with specific regulations
- **Frequency**: Varies by regulation
- **Objective**: Ensure legal compliance
- **Preparation Time**: Ongoing readiness required
- **Documentation Level**: Exhaustive documentation
- **Follow-up**: Mandatory remediation timelines

#### Penetration Testing
Technical security assessments:
- **Scope**: Technical vulnerabilities
- **Frequency**: Annual or bi-annual
- **Objective**: Identify security weaknesses
- **Preparation Time**: 2-3 weeks for logistics
- **Documentation Level**: Technical configurations
- **Follow-up**: Vulnerability remediation

### Pre-Audit Preparation Checklist

**Gap Analysis**

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Customer Relationship Management (CRM) systems are the backbone of modern sales and customer service operations. Integrating your CRM with our platform unlocks powerful automation capabilities, eliminates manual data entry, and provides a unified view of customer interactions. This comprehensive guide covers all aspects of CRM integration, from basic setup to advanced workflow automation, helping you maximize the value of both systems.

### Understanding CRM Integration Benefits

Before diving into technical details, it's important to understand why CRM integration is transformative for businesses:

#### Operational Efficiency
**Eliminate Manual Data Entry**: When systems are integrated, customer data flows automatically between platforms. This means:
- No more copying and pasting customer information
- Reduced human error in data transfer
- Time savings of 5-10 hours per week per team member
- Consistent data across all systems
- Real-time synchronization of updates

**Streamlined Workflows**: Integration enables sophisticated automation:
- Automatic ticket creation from CRM activities
- Status updates synchronized across platforms
- Triggered actions based on CRM events
- Seamless handoffs between teams
- Unified reporting and analytics

**Enhanced Customer Experience**: Integrated systems provide:
- Complete customer history at fingertips
- Faster response times to inquiries
- Personalized interactions based on CRM data
- Proactive service based on CRM insights
- Consistent experience across touchpoints

### Integration Architecture Overview

Our platform supports multiple integration patterns to accommodate different technical requirements and use cases:

#### API-Based Integration
The most flexible and powerful integration method:
- **RESTful API**: Industry-standard HTTP-based communication
- **GraphQL API**: Efficient data fetching with precise field selection
- **Real-time Sync**: Millisecond-level data synchronization
- **Batch Processing**: Efficient bulk data operations
- **Bidirectional Sync**: Two-way data flow between systems

#### Webhook Integration
Event-driven integration for real-time updates:
- **Event Triggers**: Respond to specific CRM events
- **Instant Notifications**: Zero-delay event propagation
- **Lightweight Protocol**: Minimal overhead and complexity
- **Retry Logic**: Automatic retry for failed deliveries
- **Security**: HMAC signature verification

#### Native Connectors
Pre-built integrations for popular CRM platforms:
- **One-Click Setup**: No coding required
- **Maintained by Us**: Automatic updates for API changes
- **Best Practices**: Built-in optimization and error handling
- **Support Included**: Direct assistance for connector issues
- **Regular Updates**: New features added continuously

### Salesforce Integration Deep Dive

#### Connection Methods

**OAuth 2.0 Authentication**

<ConnectedApp>

#### Data Synchronization

**Sync Strategies**

2. **Incremental Sync**: Ongoing updates

3. **Real-time Sync**: Instant updates

#### Salesforce-Specific Features

### HubSpot Integration Guide

    "Authorization": "Bearer YOUR_API_KEY",

1. Document CRM API capabilities

**Design Considerations**
- API rate limits
- Data volume estimates

#### Implementation Approach

**REST API Integration Template**
```python
import requests
import json
from datetime import datetime

class CRMIntegration:
    def __init__(self, api_key, crm_endpoint):
        self.api_key = api_key
        self.crm_endpoint = crm_endpoint
        self.platform_api = "https://api.platform.com/v2"
    
    def sync_contacts(self):
        # Fetch from CRM
        crm_contacts = self.get_crm_contacts()
        
        # Transform data
        platform_contacts = self.transform_contacts(crm_contacts)
        
        # Update platform
        for contact in platform_contacts:
            self.upsert_platform_contact(contact)
    
    def handle_webhook(self, event_data):
        # Parse CRM event
        event_type = event_data.get('type')
        entity = event_data.get('entity')
        
        # Route to appropriate handler
        if event_type == 'contact.created':

        elif event_type == 'contact.updated':

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: API and Webhook Integration Fundamentals
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content:
Modern software integration relies heavily on APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) and webhooks to create seamless connections between systems. Whether you're building a simple data sync or a complex multi-system workflow, understanding these integration fundamentals is crucial. This guide provides comprehensive coverage of our API and webhook capabilities, helping you design and implement robust integrations that scale with your business needs.

### Understanding Integration Concepts

Before diving into implementation details, let's establish a solid foundation:

#### APIs vs Webhooks: When to Use Each

**APIs (Pull Model)**
APIs are ideal when you need:
- On-demand data access
- Control over timing
- Complex queries
- Bulk operations
- Historical data retrieval

Example use cases:
- Generating reports on schedule
- Searching for specific records
- Bulk data imports/exports
- Real-time data queries
- System synchronization

**Webhooks (Push Model)**
Webhooks excel when you need:
- Real-time event notifications
- Reduced polling overhead
- Event-driven workflows
- Loose coupling between systems
- Scalable integrations

Example use cases:
- Instant notifications of changes
- Triggering automated workflows
- Keeping systems synchronized
- Event logging and auditing
- Multi-system orchestration

### API Integration Deep Dive

Our REST API provides comprehensive access to platform functionality:

#### API Architecture

**RESTful Design Principles**
- **Resource-Based**: URLs represent resources (nouns)
- **HTTP Methods**: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE
- **Stateless**: Each request contains all information
- **JSON Format**: Standard data interchange format
- **Versioning**: Backward compatibility guaranteed

**Base URL Structure**
```
https://api.platform.com/v2/{resource}
```

Where:
- `v2` indicates API version
- `{resource}` is the entity type (customers, orders, etc.)

#### Authentication Methods

**API Key Authentication**
Simplest method for server-to-server communication:

```bash
curl -X GET https://api.platform.com/v2/customers \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json"
```

Best practices:
- Store keys securely (environment variables)
- Use different keys for different environments
- Rotate keys regularly
- Monitor key usage
- Implement key scoping

**OAuth 2.0 Flow**
For user-authorized access:

1. **Authorization Request**
```
https://platform.com/oauth/authorize?
  client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&
  redirect_uri=YOUR_CALLBACK&
  response_type=code&
  scope=read_customers+write_orders
```

2. **Token Exchange**
```python
import requests

token_response = requests.post(
    'https://api.platform.com/oauth/token',
    data={
        'grant_type': 'authorization_code',
        'code': auth_code,
        'client_id': client_id,
        'client_secret': client_secret
    }
)
```

3. **API Access**
```python
api_response = requests.get(
    'https://api.platform.com/v2/customers',
    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {access_token}'}
)
```

#### Common API Operations

**Creating Resources**
```python
# Create a new customer
import requests
import json

customer_data = {
    "name": "Acme Corporation",
    "email": "contact@acme.com",
    "plan": "professional",
    "custom_fields": {
        "industry": "Technology",
        "size": "50-100"
    }
}

response = requests.post(
    'https://api.platform.com/v2/customers',
    headers={
        'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    },
    data=json.dumps(customer_data)
)

if response.status_code == 201:
    new_customer = response.json()
    print(f"Created customer with ID: {new_customer['id']}")
```

**Reading Resources**
```python
# Get customer with filtering and pagination
params = {
    'filter': 'plan:professional',
    'sort': 'created_at:desc',
    'page': 1,
    'per_page': 50,
    'fields': 'id,name,email,created_at'
}

response = requests.get(
    'https://api.platform.com/v2/customers',
    headers={'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY'},
    params=params
)

customers = response.json()
print(f"Found {customers['total']} customers")
```

**Updating Resources**
```python
# Update customer information
update_data = {
    "email": "newemail@acme.com",
    "custom_fields": {
        "last_contact": "2024-07-20"
    }
}

response = requests.patch(
    f'https://api.platform.com/v2/customers/{customer_id}',
    headers={
        'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    },
    data=json.dumps(update_data)
)
```

**Bulk Operations**
```python
# Bulk create/update customers
bulk_data = {
    "operations": [
        {
            "method": "POST",
            "resource": "/customers",
            "data": {"name": "Customer 1", "email": "cust1@example.com"}
        },
        {
            "method": "PATCH",
            "resource": "/customers/123",
            "data": {"status": "active"}
        }
    ]
}

response = requests.post(
    'https://api.platform.com/v2/bulk',
    headers={
        'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    },
    data=json.dumps(bulk_data)
)
```

#### Advanced API Features

**Field Selection**
Optimize bandwidth by requesting only needed fields:
```
GET /v2/customers?fields=id,name,email,plan
```

**Nested Resource Expansion**
Retrieve related data in a single request:
```
GET /v2/orders?expand=customer,line_items.product
```

**Conditional Requests**
Use ETags for efficient caching:
```python
# First request
response = requests.get(url)
etag = response.headers.get('ETag')

# Subsequent request
response = requests.get(
    url,
    headers={'If-None-Match': etag}
)

if response.status_code == 304:
    print("Data hasn't changed")
```

**Rate Limiting**
Our API implements intelligent rate limiting:
- Standard: 1000 requests/hour
- Professional: 5000 requests/hour
- Enterprise: Custom limits

Rate limit headers:
```
X-RateLimit-Limit: 5000
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 4999
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1627890000
```

Handling rate limits:
```python
def api_request_with_retry(url, headers):
    max_retries = 3
    retry_delay = 1
    
    for attempt in range(max_retries):
        response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
        
        if response.status_code == 429:
            retry_after = int(response.headers.get('Retry-After', retry_delay))
            time.sleep(retry_after)
            retry_delay *= 2
            continue
            
        return response
    
    raise Exception("Max retries exceeded")
```

### Webhook Integration Mastery

Webhooks provide real-time event notifications:

#### Webhook Setup

**Registering Webhooks**
```python
webhook_config = {
    "url": "https://your-app.com/webhooks/platform",
    "events": [
        "customer.created",
        "customer.updated",
        "order.placed",
        "subscription.changed"
    ],
    "secret": "your-webhook-secret",
    "active": True
}

response = requests.post(
    'https://api.platform.com/v2/webhooks',
    headers={
        'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_API_KEY',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    },
    data=json.dumps(webhook_config)
)
```

**Webhook Payload Structure**
```json
{
    "id": "evt_1234567890",
    "type": "customer.created",
    "created": "2024-07-20T10:30:00Z",
    "data": {
        "object": {
            "id": "cust_abc123",
            "name": "New Customer",
            "email": "new@customer.com",
            "created_at": "2024-07-20T10:30:00Z"

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Comprehensive Customer Data Retention Policy
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content: At Springfield Co, our customer data retention policy is designed to comply with all relevant regulations and to protect customer privacy. We retain customer data for a period of seven years after the end of the customer relationship, unless a longer retention period is required by law. Our policy covers the following: 1) Data Types: We retain account information, transaction records, communication logs, and support tickets. 2) Retention Schedule: Data is reviewed annually and deleted when no longer required. 3) Secure Deletion: Data is securely deleted using industry-standard methods. 4) Legal Holds: If data is subject to a legal hold, it will be retained until the hold is lifted. 5) Customer Rights: Customers may request deletion of their data, subject to legal and contractual obligations. 6) Data Access: Only authorized personnel may access retained data. 7) Policy Review: The policy is reviewed and updated annually. 8) Contact: For questions, contact privacy@springfieldco.com. (Word count: ~520)

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: How We Manage and Delete Customer Data
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content: Springfield Co is committed to responsible data management and deletion practices. Our process includes: 1) Data Inventory: We maintain a detailed inventory of all customer data. 2) Access Controls: Only authorized staff can access or delete data. 3) Deletion Requests: Customers can request deletion of their data via our support portal. 4) Secure Deletion: Data is deleted using secure wipe protocols. 5) Audit Trails: All deletions are logged and reviewed. 6) Data Minimization: We only collect and retain data necessary for business operations. 7) Retention Exceptions: Some data may be retained longer for legal or regulatory reasons. 8) Policy Updates: We update our practices as regulations evolve. 9) Transparency: We notify customers of significant changes. 10) Contact: For more information, email privacy@springfieldco.com. (Word count: ~510)

get_relevant_knowledge_articles.title: Your Rights and Our Responsibilities Under the Data Retention Policy
get_relevant_knowledge_articles.content: Our data retention policy at Springfield Co is built on transparency and respect for customer rights. 1) Right to Access: Customers can request a copy of their retained data. 2) Right to Rectification: Customers can request corrections to their data. 3) Right to Erasure: Customers may request deletion of their data, subject to legal requirements. 4) Data Portability: We provide data in a portable format upon request. 5) Security: We use encryption and access controls to protect retained data. 6) Breach Notification: Customers are notified within 72 hours of any data breach. 7) Policy Review: The policy is reviewed annually. 8) Employee Training: All staff are trained on data retention and privacy. 9) Regulatory Compliance: We comply with GDPR, CCPA, and other regulations. 10) Contact: For rights requests, email privacy@springfieldco.com.
